question_text:
If $\mathbf{A} = \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix},$ then its transpose is given by
\[\mathbf{A}^T = \begin{pmatrix} a & c \\ b & d \end{pmatrix}.\]Given that $\mathbf{A}^T = \mathbf{A}^{-1},$ find $a^2 + b^2 + c^2 + d^2.$
response:
We have
\[\begin{align*}\mathbf{AA}^T&=\mathbf{I}_2\\
\Rightarrow\qquad \begin{pmatrix} a & b \\ c & d \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix}a & c \\ b & d\end{pmatrix}&= \begin{pmatrix}1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1\end{pmatrix}\\
\Rightarrow\qquad \begin{pmatrix} a^2 + b^2 & ac+bd \\ ca+db & c^2+d^2 \end{pmatrix}&=\begin{pmatrix}1 & 0\\ 0 & 1\end{pmatrix},
\end{align*}\]which implies
\[ac + bd = ca + db= 0,\quad a^2+b^2=c^2+d^2.\]
The equation $a^2+b^2=c^2+d^2$ can be rearranged to give $$(a-b)^2+(c-d)^2=0\Rightarrow \boxed{a=b,c=d.}$$
Finally, we have $$a^2 + b^2 = a^2 + c^2 \Rightarrow 2b^2 = 2c^2 \Rightarrow b=c.$$
